title: WAF vs SFU MCL 2024 Qualifier: Travis Head, Glenn Maxwell Help Washington Defeat San Francisco By 6 Wickets To Enter Finals
body:
WAF vs SFU MCL 2024 Qualifier: Washington Freedom (WAF) brushed aside San Francisco Unicorns (SFU) by six wickets in the Qualifier of the ongoing Major League Cricket (MLC) season 2024 at the Grand Prairie Stadium on July 26 (Friday). With the win, Washington are set to make their maiden Major League Cricket final appearance and are primed to win it as well. Led by Steve Smith, Washington have been beaten just once in the entire tournament.

San Francisco will have one more opportunity as they will face Texas Super kIngs (TSK) in the Challenger match, and whoever wins that match will face WAF in the finals.

ALSO ON ABP Live | Suryakumar Yadav Reflects On 'Special' Bond With Coach Gautam Gambhir From KKR Days Ahead Of IND vs SL Series

Fifties From Travis Head & Glenn Maxwell Take Washington To Maiden MLC Final

Coming to the match, Washington Freedom were given the target of 146 runs in 20 overs. They faced a rocky start as captain Steve Smith threw his wicket away early into the innings trying to play an uncharacteristic shot. However, opener Travis Head, was once again in a destructive mood as he brought up his fifth consecutive fifty in the tournament. He was supported by compatriot Glenn Maxwell who also brought up a fifty in just 22 balls and steered Washington Freedom to a comfortable six-wicket victory with four overs to spare.

Rachin Ravindra's 4-Fer Deals San Francisco Heavy Blow

Earlier in the match, San Francisco were put in to bat first after Steve Smith won the toss. Finn Allen and Jake Fraser-McGurk started shakily and lost their wickets not long after. SFU were in grave trouble as they found themselves 67-5 after 11 overs. However, Core Anderson and Hassan Khan stitched a good partnership to take their team out of trouble. Eventually, SFU finished with 145-10 in 19.1 overs.

Rachin Ravindra was the standout pick of the bowlers for Washington as he scalped four wickets in just 2.4 overs giving away only 11 runs.
summary:
* Washington Freedom (WAF) defeated San Francisco Unicorns (SFU) by 6 wickets in the Qualifier match of the MLC 2024 season at the Grand Prairie Stadium on July 26.
* With this win, Washington Freedom have secured a spot in the final, their maiden MLC final appearance.
* San Francisco Unicorns will face Texas Super Kings (TSK) in the Challenger match, and the winner of that match will play Washington Freedom in the final.
* Travis Head and Glenn Maxwell scored fifties to help Washington chase down the target of 146 runs in 20 overs.
* Rachin Ravindra took 4 wickets for 11 runs in 2.4 overs to help restrict San Francisco Unicorns to 145-10 in 19.1 overs.

title: 'Now that I've taken my helmet off, I can show the person I am'
body:
Ricky Ponting is the coach of Washington Freedom in Major League Cricket 2024 ©MLC

In an exclusive interview with Cricbuzz, Ricky Ponting talks about his coaching philosophy, how to work with maverick talents like Glenn Maxwell, his stint with Delhi Capitals, and why he's gone from being a hard-nosed Australian captain to someone that is more widely appreciated. Excerpts:

This is your first stint in the franchise world outside of the IPL, if I'm not wrong. Why America as a coaching destination?

Well, a lot of friends of mine and coaches and guys that I'm pretty close to played in MLC last year. And during the IPL, it was spoken about a little bit, last year even about potential for some growth here and how big the game already was in the US. Everyone I spoke to last year, had a really good time and enjoyed the tournament and felt that it will just get bigger and better. So I wanted to get involved early on to have a look at it.

And I think all of us that are here now play a role in promoting the game. Even though I'm here coaching and looking after this team Washington Freedom, I think the fact that ex-international players are being involved in a tournament like this will hopefully help it grow.

Is it also a means to carve out a legacy for the Freedom franchise by leading them in their nascent stages, and basically formulating that culture, identity, and the way they go about their cricket in a manner that is on course with your beliefs and other decision makers around you?

Yeah, absolutely. I think Cameron White and Shawn Bradstreet were here last year along with Michael Klinger. I think they'd set a pretty good culture. The team made the playoffs, but didn't go all the way. The plan going forward for us this year was to make sure we have sustained success and as you say, build the right culture for this franchise. I think I've been lucky to be around a lot of really successful teams as a player and as a coach, and got a pretty good grasp on cultural sort of matters. It's what makes me a good coach, and what I think makes people enjoy me being around them. So that's what I continue to work on every day. Talking to a lot of the guys here, there's a lot of them that haven't been around a lot of international experience like I've been able to bring here. So that makes it more enjoyable for me to work in that sort of environment.

There are about 15 Aussies in the MLC. Most of them are your star Australian cricketers that were part of the World Cup squad. Now compare that to The Hundred where there are only four Australia cricketers. We know Aussie cricketers are a golden asset for any league, so is the cricketing world order changing right now in front of our eyes?

I think the whole game is in quite an interesting phase right now with different tournaments almost popping up every year. A lot of those tournaments overlap. Even the BBL in Australia overlaps with ILT20 and also the SA20. It's good and bad for players, I guess. Players get a chance to play in lots of different competitions. But with the overlapping like we've seen with San Francisco Unicorns' Matthew Short leaving MLC early to go to play in The Hundred, that's one thing I'm not a big fan of. I don't like seeing players leave early to go and play in a different tournament, and I think it's something that needs to be addressed going forward. I think there need to be certain windows cut out for every tournament - make sure there's clean air for that tournament to get over and done with, and keep their players for the big games. I've been there before with the BBL, where you sign players up at the start and you make the finals and you lose your stars when the big games come around. That's not ideal for anybody.

But I think a lot of the players have probably had a similar attitude like me, that they wanted to have a look at MLC in the early days. Get involved early and hopefully be part of the growth. Even having someone like Pat Cummins, Steve Smith, Travis Head, Glenn Maxwell here. As you say there are a lot of big name Australian players playing this year. And I think that's great for the tournament.

Was there also the lure of leaving your imprints on a franchise and making a legacy for yourself?

I don't look at it that way. I don't look at leaving legacy or imprints. I just want to get here and do the best job that I can and make sure that the players understand what I'm all about and how much I love working with good players and making them better. More importantly, understand how important winning is to me. That's the first thing I say to any group that I come to - that anything we do from here until the end of this tournament, we'll find ways to to get better and win. That attitude certainly seems to work so far this year.

With the type of personality you are, you're all in when you take up an assignment. It has come to my knowledge that you were heavily active on the team WhatsApp group, and tried to stay on top of what was going on in the practice sessions even while you were in the Caribbean. So what sort of involvement can we expect from you with Freedom in the future? Especially considering the task of bridging the gap between domestic talent and international talent.

It actually wasn't ideal for me this year as my first year with this team, considering the overlap with the World Cup. But when Michael Klinger rang me and asked me to think about the job, the first thing I said was, 'Look, I know I'm actually going to be in the Caribbean, and I'll be commentating in the World Cup final. So it's not gonna be perfect for you. It's not gonna be perfect for me.' But, I think our conversations first started maybe in about January when I was working in the BBL. Right back then when I decided to go ahead and do it, then I was the one that was reaching out to make sure we signed the right players as well. So, my involvement sort of stems back to getting Travis Head, Glenn Maxwell, these guys to come and sign here and play with us.

When I'm here, I'm obviously heavily involved. Even some of the players the last couple of days have come to me and said we can't believe how actively involved you are with throwing balls all day, every day and being out in the field and running drills and things like that. But that's my opportunity to make players better. So I don't ever want to miss a minute or a practice session where I'm not giving my best to make every player in the squad as good as they can be. That's just the way that I am. It's ingrained in me. I'm not going to sit back and waste any time around cricket. And that's one of the other things I say to the boys first off is I don't like lazy people. I don't like people with talent that don't try and get the most out of themselves. So if I can show that attitude as a retired player and almost impose on them the way that I want them to go about their cricket while I'm here then hopefully that only makes them better.

'I've played 15 years of cricket with him [Justin Langer]. I actually didn't even look at him or shake his hand until the game or games were over. So that's just my competitive nature coming out' ©BCCI

As a captain, you had mentioned in your autobiography that you asked the team not to address Kevin Pietersen as 'KP', or for that matter not call any of the Englishmen by their nicknames during the 2006-07 home Ashes. You stated you were too chummy with them in the previous series and now wanted to impose yourselves on them. There was also another side to it where Justin Langer once revealed how you asked the team to be humble before the final English wicket fell in the Perth Test when you were about to clinch that series. Does franchise cricket allow for these intense mind games? Have you ever done something similar to that as a coach?

Yes and I'd love to give a bit of an example for that as well. One thing that I always struggled with the IPL, obviously, was that a lot of the Indian guys play in the national team together and you tend to get to the ground really early - about two hours before the game starts. And a lot of the players sort of catch up on the ground and put their arms around each other and give them a cuddle whenever they meet each other before the game starts, but I'd never do that. Justin Langer this year, for instance. I've played 15 years of cricket with him. I actually didn't even look at him or shake his hand until the game or games were over. So that's just my competitive nature coming out.

It probably doesn't change the outcome but I think it sets a pretty good idea to the opposition that I'm there to get my job done and to have my team win that game of cricket. I'll probably have been a little bit more relaxed here to be honest. I actually saw Shane Watson before our last game but the only reason we crossed paths was we were having team photos on the ground, otherwise I would have stayed away from him. Pravin Amre has been an assistant coach with me at Delhi for seven years. I didn't see him until after the game was over so that's just me, but everyone's different I guess.

What Rishabh's been through last year is one that's probably the most emotional, with how close I was with him and what he went through and the fear of all of us that he might not play cricket again. Seeing him back and doing what he's doing and leading DC, I think it's a pretty emotional time for everyone.

***

Six IPL seasons with DC is quite a long time. How have you evolved as a coach over the years at DC?

I actually think even though I'm quite intense, I'm a bit more relaxed as a coach now than I once was. I'm better at understanding an individual's own preparation better than I probably once was. Coming reasonably new out of the game and straight into coaching, it was easy for me to sit back and expect everyone to train the same way that I did. But that doesn't necessarily bring the best out in people.

So even in this tournament, yes we've played well, but I think we've probably only had one or two compulsory training sessions on the way. The rest of them have been optional. I've left it up to the players. I've told them that I've got full trust in them to understand what they need, as far as their preparation is concerned, if they don't come to train, that's fine. But if they come to training, make sure they come with a real intent and purpose to get something out of it and try and improve. So I think that's probably the biggest thing. I try to learn more about people quicker and understand who they are as people more so than cricketers. I think if I do that I gain respect back pretty quickly and then hopefully they'll perform for you.

You mentioned the way you adapted to allow individuals the liberty to prepare as per their individual preferences. Would you want to add to this list where you would have learned something new which quashed or sort of negated some of your beliefs regarding your own coaching philosophy?

I'm still learning every day. And if I'm not then I'm probably wasting my time because you get so many people around you that you can learn from. Little things I've tried to do in this tournament is that this group has played a lot of golf together since we've been here. And one thing I've tried to do is make sure that I'm playing in the groups with the local boys for five hours a day, rather than playing with Maxwell, Smith and Head, all the guys I know. I'm wasting five hours if I do that when I can be playing with Gous and Obus and Justin Dill and these guys. That's a perfect opportunity for me to learn more about them and spend time with them and have them understand that I actually chose to play with you guys this day over playing with the Aussie guys. So I've just tried to maximise my time with them here but also make sure that I've given them their own space. I think that's another important thing for me as a coach now is you gotta understand that you are a coach, you're not one of the players.

In an interview with Cricbuzz three years back, you had mentioned how you were a relationship-based coach. Over the course of six years you might have built some strong interpersonal relationships at DC. Can you recall having some moving moments with some of the individuals at DC that will kind of stay with you for the longest time?

I haven't spoken publicly about not being there next year. I sort of let it go because I was here and been paying pretty close attention to what I'm doing here. Look, I had a great time there. DC, for me, was like my second home and my family was there with me for a month or five weeks in the last three or four years. It hasn't always been the most successful franchise. So we tried to build a real family inclusive environment where everyone was treated the same and everyone was on the same page.

I mean what Rishabh's been through last year is one that's probably the most emotional, with how close I was with him and what he went through and the fear of all of us that he might not play cricket again. Seeing him back and doing what he's doing and leading DC, I think it's a pretty emotional time for everyone.

So it is what it is, we've decided to part ways and we decided to move on but that doesn't mean that I won't be coaching again. I'm very keen to get back involved in the IPL. There might be a few opportunities coming up and we'll see what happens over the next few weeks.

You have been fabulous at nurturing young talent during your time as the Australian captain as well as a coach in the IPL. Speaking to some of the domestics at Washington Freedom, they haven't been short of singing your praises on the experience they had with you. What is the first quality you want to see in a young player?

It depends where you are in a scouting role, or a coaching role. You want to see skill and talent first. But my coaching mantra is based around four words. That's attitude, effort, commitment, and care. I think as a coach, it's much easier to coach skill than it is to try and change someone's attitude, or character. So, give me the right attitude and the right effort, and the right commitment, then I feel that I can make those players better, but you give me the highest skill players that don't want to change, then they're wasting everyone's time.

Even in a tournament like this, where there's been a lot of players that I've seen, I sit back and say, 'Well, that kid's good, he's got some real talent.' A lot of those are the ones that we've got here, which has made working here that bit more fun. I've obviously had a lot of players on the other end of the scale. Even at DC there's a lot of players that I've coached there that are highly talented players that I haven't been able to change. It's disappointing for me and it's also disappointing for the player not to be able to understand and see how much better they can become if they really want to.

Piggybacking on what you've said there is also this curious case of supremely talented Prithvi Shaw that went from the most promising to being benched in the final season at DC. How does the coach's role become important in that situation where you have to handle people with truckloads of talent who are sort of outliers?

I mean to start with I don't like talking about individual players, but Prithvi shouldn't be an outlier. He should be someone that's in every team; the first pick in most teams with the skill that he's got. He's had a chance to represent India as a youngster, making a hundred on his Test debut. And as you say, halfway through this year, we couldn't find a slot for him in our DC team. So that's disappointing for me as a coach not to be able to make certain players better and get the best out of them. But sometimes there's only so much you can give and so many times you can try. When you feel like you're not making players better and they're not doing what you need for the team, then you've got to look for other players that can do it for you.

So that then comes back to the player. With him in particular I've had a lot of chats with him, a lot of conversations to try and make him a better cricketer. I mean, he's still a young man. And he's still a very talented young player. And hopefully one day the penny really drops for him and he works out what he needs to do to be the best cricketer that he can be.

Travis Head, Steve Smith and Glenn Maxwell are part of the Washington Freedom setup ©Getty

Marcus Stoinis mentioned not too long back that Maxwell, one of your Freedom stars, is the most talented batter he has ever seen till date. An Australian media outlet reported about his Test comeback on the tour of Sri Lanka. It is this outrageous talent of his that has had Cricket Australia toying with the idea of having him back in the Test scheme of things time and again. Obviously, we all know the range of strokes that he has. That makes him extra special. But coming from your X-ray eyes, if you can dissect Maxwell the batsman, his mind and the superhuman talent that he possesses.

I think Glenn's name quite often gets thrown up when it's a subcontinent tour because of what he can do with bat and ball. He gives the Australian team a lot of flexibility as far as a second spin bowling option or even sometimes a third spin bowling if they go that way. I've known Glenn for a long time, and hopefully he gets the chance to play Test cricket again. But he's really made his name for himself in white ball cricket. He's had some outrageously good moments throughout his career.

Guys like that who have that X factor talent about them, I don't like to talk to them too much about their cricket. You just have to be really careful with the way that you phrase things in the way that you speak to them. Because for players that have got that sort of talent, you don't want to get in their way. You don't want to have something that you said in the back of their mind that can actually stop that X factor play coming out. So for me, it's much easier to coach the guys that have less talent and less skill because I think I can help them and give them things that they can think about that can make them better.

And Travis is exactly the same right now. I mentioned in one of our postgame chats the other night that there's a lot of things that I could talk to Travis about with his batting but I'm not going to because it's all good. It's going so well that I don't need to get in the back of his head. I don't want to be this little voice sitting on his shoulder. I want him to play with freedom and keep doing what he's doing and Maxwell was a bit the same. So it's hard to dissect. Now that AB de Villiers and those guys aren't around, Glenn and Suryakumar are probably the most complete 360-degree players in the modern game. And with what he can bring with the other dimensions to his cricket - his fielding and with the ball - he's obviously a very, very good player.

Do you think people like Glenn Maxwell are a prototype of a T20 batter 10 years from now?

Glenn probably almost had some of this flamboyance coached out of him when he was young. He got out a lot playing the reverse sweep and the switch hit when he was younger. Had coaches left, right and centre and commentators and media, and probably even me being one in certain times were questioning why he was trying to do that. But if he hadn't worked on it then and he hadn't got so good at playing it, then we wouldn't see the Glenn Maxwell of now. So he's shown a lot of courage to continue to play the way that he wants to play. For 10 or 12 years now he's reaped the rewards whether that's on-field performance or certainly the money he's made from the game has been on the back of the skill set that he's had.

Since we have touched the future and you are one of the most prominent voices in the game, where do you see the international cricket calendar heading towards? How does one maintain the sanctity of Test cricket? And also be mindful that franchise cricket is the real cash cow now for the international players living outside of India. There is an argument to play only Test cricket as bilaterals and the white ball cricket only in ICC tournaments. What's your opinion on that?

I don't want to see any international cricket played less. I just think it's something that's been sort of happening even when I was playing. Probably when the IPL started up was when this sort of stuff started to happen. Conversations were around about franchise cricket compared to international cricket. It's got to the point now where franchise cricket is probably the most talked about and certainly the most played because there are so many leagues around the world that have been allowed to start up, and international cricket is trying to slot in around these tournaments now, which is the opposite way that it used to be.

So there's some great challenges there but I would hate to see one day cricket, for instance, only played during World Cup years. I think there's a time and a place for all three formats. Where the game gets in trouble is when we start comparing one format to the other and immediately playing a Test match on the back of a 50-over or T20 World Cup. A great example is the last T20 World Cup that was in Australia that England won, they stayed on in Australia after that to play some one-dayers against Australia and I took my son to the MCG with his U-11 team to watch a contest between Australia and England. There were something like 8000 people there. When I was playing Australia vs England at the MCG, it was 80,000 plus every game. So that's the scheduling, and that's the unfortunate thing about it. There's still as many people watching the game as ever, they're just choosing what they want to watch and when they want to watch it.

If you've just had an international Test series, don't expect the attendance to be strong for the ODI series against Sri Lanka in the West Indies immediately after it for they'll be watching it at home. So that's the one thing we have to understand. But look, I'm not sure where it's headed. Well I know where it's headed. Obviously more and more franchise-based cricket where I think we're going to see in a lot of countries like New Zealand, like the West Indies have been doing for a long time and maybe Sri Lanka, these sorts of countries that don't get paid a lot to play international cricket then they're going to be choosing franchise cricket over international stuff which is a little bit sad, but that's the reality of the world right now.

For the most part in your playing days, you were someone who non-Australian fans hated to love because of your skill, how unabashedly pro-team or pro-teammates you were, which obviously the fans from the rest of the world were not fond of. Now after retirement that is exactly the quality the fans from MI, which you coached once, DC or Freedom now love about you. You won a lot of trophies as a player, but seem to be winning more hearts as a coach. Did you expect this turn around?

I don't know if I expected it, or I didn't really care too much to be honest. When I was playing, I mean everything you said there was right. All I cared about was the guys on my team and making sure I was doing the right thing by them as people and players and getting results for them. When I was the captain of the Australian cricket team, I looked at myself as a protector, my job was to protect my teammates and look after them. I was a senior player and had lots of younger players coming in. The cold, hard facts of it is that international cricket can be a tough, lonely place. Some young players need older people like me around to look after them and protect them.

The way I describe it is when I was playing, I had a helmet on, I didn't say anything, didn't give anything away. But now that I've retired and taken my helmet off, I can actually start to show the world and people that maybe that wasn't me as a person. That was me trying to do my job as an Australian cricket captain. I want people to enjoy the time that they have when I'm around them, basically. If that means that I protect them or look after them or make them better, then at the end of the day that's what my job is.

© Cricbuzz

title: [Watch] Glenn Maxwell Destroys Pakistan Origin Bowler In MLC 2024 With A Massive 103-Metre Six
body:
Glenn Maxwell's massive six vs Hassan Khan (X.com)

Glenn Maxwell smashed as many as five sixes on Friday (July 26) in Qualifier 1 of the Major League Cricket (MLC) 2024 at Grand Prairie Stadium, Dallas, where San Francisco Unicorns met Washington Freedom for a place in the final.

Playing for Washington, Maxwell remained unbeaten on 54* off 23 balls, which helped his side see off an easy 146-run target in just 15.3 overs with seven wickets in hand.

Among Maxwell's insane hittings, the one he smashed against Pakistan spinner Hassan Khan attracted a lot of attention. It came during the 15th over of Washington's innings, when Maxwell picked up a fullish tossed-up delivery by the left-arm spinner, and sent it way over long on for a 103-metre six.

Watch - Maxwell's Audacious 103 M Six In MLC 2024

Apart from Maxwell's brisk, Travis Head made headlines as well, smashing 77 off just 44 balls to get the job done with ease.

Washington will now wait for the winner of the Challenger, where San Francisco Unicorns will go up against Texas Super Kings in a do-or-die affair.
summary:
* The article reports on Qualifier 1 of the MLC 2024, where Washington Freedom faced San Francisco Unicorns at the Grand Prairie Stadium in Dallas.
* Glenn Maxwell, playing for Washington Freedom, top-scored with an unbeaten 54* off 23 balls, helping his team chase down a target of 146 runs in 15.3 overs with 7 wickets in hand.
* Maxwell hit 5 sixes, including a notable 103-meter six against Pakistani spinner Hassan Khan.
* Travis Head also contributed to Washington's win, scoring 77 off 44 balls.
* With this win, Washington Freedom have secured a spot in the final, while San Francisco Unicorns will face Texas Super Kings in the Challenger (a do-or-die match) to determine the other finalist.

title: Watch: Corey Anderson's gravity defying one handed stunner sends Faf du Plessis packing
body:
San Francisco Unicorns beat Texas Super Kings in the Major League Cricket 2024 Challenger on July 26 to reach the finals. Unicorns were asked to bat first and put up a challenging 200 on the board as Fin Allen dazzled with 101 off just 53. Devon Conway and Faf du Plessis were cruising toward the target before Corey Anderson showed his sheer athleticism to dismiss the South African in the fifth over.

Texas had amassed 55 runs in 4.1 overs as Carmi le Roux delivered a back-of-a-length delivery that angled across Du Plessis and was bit wide. The Texas skipper tried to reach out to the ball and toed it towards mid-off. On any other day, the ball would have sailed over the fielder, but Anderson judged, waited, jumped at the right time, and stretched his left hand to grab a stunner.

“It was moments like that which will help us going further (on his one-handed catch), Faf has been playing well right through the tournament, so that catch helped us to stall some of the momentum away from them,” said Anderson after the game.

Here’s the video of Anderson’s catch:

Also Read: Nicole Bolton opens up on former coach’s brutal comparison

It was important to break the match in the powerplay: Faf

The former South Africa captain walked back after scoring 45 off 22, while Conway (62* off 38) remained unbeaten. But no other Texas batter chipped in with a valuable onslaught in the middle, and the required run rate kept raking up. Joshua Tromp played a sublime knock of an unbeaten 56* off 36, but that proved to be just not enough as San Francisco clinched the victory by 10 runs.

Also Read: Suryakumar Yadav delivers jestful remark to past remark from Gautam Gambhir

“I thought 185 was a par score here, we started off well (with the bat), it was important to break the match in the powerplay, but we lost quick wickets in the middle-overs, we did show a lot of fight in the back-end, but left too much in the end,” said Du Plessis after the game.
summary:
**Match Result:** San Francisco Unicorns defeated Texas Super Kings by 10 runs in the 2024 Challenger on July 26 to reach the finals.

**Key Performances:**

* Fin Allen scored 101 off 53 balls for San Francisco Unicorns.
* Faf du Plessis scored 45 off 22 balls for Texas Super Kings before being dismissed by a stunning one-handed catch by Corey Anderson.
* Devon Conway scored 62* off 38 balls for Texas Super Kings.
* Joshua Tromp scored an unbeaten 56* off 36 balls for Texas Super Kings.

**Turning Point:** Corey Anderson's incredible one-handed catch in the fifth over to dismiss Faf du Plessis, which helped stall the momentum of Texas Super Kings.

**Post-Match Quotes:**

* Corey Anderson: "It was moments like that which will help us going further... Faf has been playing well right through the tournament, so that catch helped us to stall some of the momentum away from them."
* Faf du Plessis: "I thought 185 was a par score here, we started off well (with the bat), it was important to break the match in the powerplay, but we lost quick wickets in the middle-overs, we did show a lot of fight in the back-end, but left too much in the end."

title: Pakistan-born Hassan Khan's all-round performance propels Unicorns to MLC 2024 final
body:
Pakistan's young all-rounder Hassan Khan showcased an exceptional performance, both with the bat and ball, to lead the San Francisco Unicorns to victory in the Eliminator round against the Texas Super Kings, securing their place in the Major League Cricket (MLC) 2024 final.

After being asked to bat first, the Unicorns posted a formidable total of 200 runs for the loss of six wickets.

The highlight of their innings was Finn Allen's explosive knock of 101 runs off 53 deliveries, supported by Josh Inglis who contributed 37 runs from 25 balls. Hassan Khan played a crucial cameo, scoring 27 runs off 15 deliveries, which included four boundaries and one six.

In response, the Texas Super Kings put up a valiant fight but fell short, finishing at 190 runs for the loss of four wickets. Devon Conway remained unbeaten with a solid 62 runs, while skipper Faf du Plessis added 45 runs and Joshua Trump scored 56 runs.

Despite their efforts, the Super Kings lost the match by a narrow margin of 10 runs.

Haris Rauf struggled with the ball, going wicketless and conceding 43 runs in his four-over spell. Conversely, Hassan Khan shone with his bowling, taking the crucial wicket of Milind Kumar and giving away just 25 runs in his four overs.

With this victory, the San Francisco Unicorns will face Washington Freedom in the MLC 2024 final, scheduled for Sunday, July 28th, in Dallas.
summary:
* The San Francisco Unicorns defeated the Texas Super Kings in the Eliminator round, securing their spot in the final.
* The Unicorns scored 200/6, led by Finn Allen's 101 off 53 balls, Josh Inglis' 37 off 25 balls, and Hassan Khan's 27 off 15 balls.
* The Texas Super Kings responded with 190/4, featuring Devon Conway's 62, Faf du Plessis' 45, and Joshua Trump's 56, but fell short by 10 runs.
* Hassan Khan excelled with the ball, taking one wicket and conceding 25 runs in four overs, while Haris Rauf struggled, going wicketless and conceding 43 runs.
* The San Francisco Unicorns will face the Washington Freedom in the MLC 2024 final on Sunday, July 28th, in Dallas.

title: WATCH: Corey Anderson’s remarkable catch to dismiss Faf Du Plessis in MLC 2024
body:
In a nail-biting clash at the Grand Prairie Stadium in Dallas, the San Francisco Unicorns (SFU) edged out the Texas Super Kings (TSK) by ten runs, securing their place in the finals of Major League Cricket 2024 (MLC). The match, a spectacle of skill and tenacity, saw several standout performances and a moment of brilliance that proved pivotal.

Corey Anderson’s stunning catch

The highlight of the match was undoubtedly the sensational catch by San Francisco’s skipper Corey Anderson. With Carmi le Roux bowling a back-of-length delivery angling wide outside off, Faf du Plessis attempted a slash shot but only managed to toe-end it. Anderson, displaying remarkable athleticism and reflexes, leapt mid-air to snatch the ball with his left hand. His incredible catch not only dismissed the dangerous du Plessis, who was threatening to take the game away within the powerplay, but it also lifted his team’s spirits with its inspirational effort.

Here is the video:

Also WATCH: Glenn Maxwell’s mammoth six against Hassan Khan in the Qualifier of MLC 2024

Path to the finals

The San Francisco Unicorns scored 200 runs for 6 wickets in their 20 overs. Finn Allen played a great innings, scoring 101 runs off 53 balls. His century was the fifth in the MLC and helped set a tough target.

The Texas Super Kings scored 190 runs for 4 wickets in their innings. Devon Conway and Joshua Tromp both scored half-centuries, but it wasn’t enough. The Texas Super Kings fell short by 10 runs, and the San Francisco Unicorns won the match by 10 runs.

With this victory, the San Francisco Unicorns have booked their spot in the finals of MLC 2024. They will face the Washington Freedom on July 29 at the Grand Prairie Stadium in Dallas. The upcoming final promises to be an exciting showdown, as both teams vie for the coveted title.
summary: The San Francisco Unicorns won a thrilling match against the Texas Super Kings by 10 runs, securing their spot in the finals of Major League Cricket 2024. The highlight of the match was Corey Anderson's spectacular catch, which lifted his team's spirits and dismissed Faf du Plessis. Finn Allen scored a century, his 101 runs off 53 balls helping the Unicorns set a target of 200 runs for 6 wickets. The Texas Super Kings replied with 190 runs for 4 wickets, but fell short. The San Francisco Unicorns will face the Washington Freedom in the finals on July 29 at the Grand Prairie Stadium in Dallas.

title: WF vs SFU Dream11 Prediction: Who Will Win?
body:
Washington Freedom will take on the San Francisco Unicorns in the Play-Off 2 match of Major League Cricket 2024.

Washington Freedom Vs San Francisco Unicorns Play-Off 2 Preview

This is the big-money match of this tournament to this point, despite the two teams having faced each other earlier this week. The winner of this one will book their place in the final.

Washington Freedom has been in scintillating form in this competition. With five wins and one loss in seven games, they finished on top of the league table with 11 points. Their superb net run rate shows how dominant this team has been throughout the tournament. With openers Travis Head and Steve Smith in the top three run-scorers and Saurabh Netravalkar the top wicket-taker this season, they will have an eye on the trophy.

San Francisco Unicorns have been equally good. They also have five wins, one loss and 11 points in the league, but are in second due to net run rate. But they have one thing over the Freedom. These two teams collided for the first time this season earlier this week, and that match was won by the Unicorns. They will look to repeat their win from the last match and confirm a place in the final.

WF Vs SFU Play-Off 2 MLC 2024: Match Details

Match: Washington Freedom Vs San Francisco Unicorns, Major League Cricket Play-Off 2

Venue: Grand Prairie Cricket Stadium, Dallas, Texas

Date & Time: Friday, July 26, 6:00 AM (IST)/ July 25, 7:30 PM (local time)

Live Broadcast and Streaming: Sony Sports Network, JioCinema App & Website

WF Vs SFU Announced Squads

Washington Freedom Announced Squad

Corey Anderson (C), Finn Allen, Matthew Short, Sherfane Rutherford, Jake Fraser-McGrk, Josh Inglis (wk), Tajinder Dhillon, Pat Cummins, Jahmar Hamilton (wk), Wiaan Mulder, Hassan Khan, Haris Rauf, Matt Henry, Karima Gore, Carmi le Roux, Sanjay Krishnamurthi, Liam Plunkett, Brody Couch, Abrar Ahmed

San Francisco Unicorns Announced Squad

Heinrich Klaasen (wk) (C), Aaron Jones, Quinton de Kock (wk), Hammad Azam, Nuaman Anwar, Michael Bracewell, Shehas Jayasuriya, Shubham Ranjane, Ryan Rickelton (wk), Harmeet Singh, Imad Wasim, Nathan ellis, Obed McCoy, Ali Sheikh, Cameron Gannon, Lance Morris, Nandre Burgerm Zaman Khan, Ayan Desai

Washington Freedom Vs San Francisco Unicorns Pitch Report

It is a solid batting pitch that can generate 180+ scores on any day, although targets of 150-170 are much more realistic. Fast bowlers will find some movement, especially early in the inning.

The ball starts sticking to the pitch as the match proceeds, which might help medium pacers with a lot of variations. Quality spinners too can muddle the middle overs.

Washington Freedom Vs San Francisco Unicorns Weather Report

With temperature in the mid-20s and high humidity, the conditions will be a little sticky at the time of the match. The humidity will also result in a lot of dew falling, especially in the second inning.

The skies will be overcast, but the chances of rain are minimal. It will also be normally windy at the time of the match.

WF Vs SFU Predicted Playing XI

Washington Freedom Predicted Playing XI

Travis Head, Steve Smith (C), Andreis Gous (wk), Rachin Ravindra, Mukhtar Ahmed, Jack Edwards, Obus Pienaar, Justin Dill, Akeal Hosein, Andrew Tye, Saurabh Netravalkar

San Francisco Unicorns Predicted Playing XI

Finn Allen, Jake Fraser-McGurk, Sanjay Krishnamurthi, Josh Inglis (wk), Sherfane Rutherford, Corey Anderson (C), Hassan Ali, Tajinder Singh, Juanoy Drysdale, Haris Rauf, Carmi de Roux

WF Vs SFU Head To Head Record

Matches Played: 02

Washington Freedom Won: 01

San Francisco Unicorns Won: 01

No Result: 00

First Played: July 23, 2023

Last Played: July 23, 2024

WF vs SFU Dream11 Prediction

This is arguably the toughest game to call this season. These two teams have been the best two sides in this tournament. And while San Francisco won this match-up just days ago, that was a very close game.

It has to be said that Washington has won their games in a more dominating fashion this season, which might make them slight favourites in this one. That is compounded by brilliant tournaments that several individuals are having in this team.

While yes, this game might be too close to call, Washington Freedom will walk into this one as slight favourites.

WF vs SFU Dream11 Prediction: Washington Freedom will defeat San Francisco Unicorns in the 23rd Match of Major League Cricket 2024

**Match Preview:**
The Washington Freedom will face the San Francisco Unicorns in the Play-Off 2 match of Major League Cricket 2024. The winner of this match will secure a spot in the final.

**Team Performance:**
Both teams have been strong performers in the tournament, with Washington Freedom finishing top of the league table with 11 points (5 wins, 1 loss) and a superb net run rate. title: Major League Cricket Playoffs – Washington Freedom Triumphant
body:
Washington Freedom convincingly beat the San Francisco Unicorns to book their place in this year’s Major League Cricket final with the elimination of MI New York in the first playoff against Texas, where the competition will crown a new winner this year. And given their stellar run in the season, where they finished on top, it seems the team representing the capital is the team to beat.

It was a dominant show all around by the Washington Freedom. Having restricted the Unicorns to 145 in 19 overs, the Washington Freedom wasted little time in chasing down the score. With destroyer-in-chief, Travis Head led the way with a dominant 77 off 44 inclusive of three sixes and ten fours. When chasing the Washington Freedom, despite losing wickets cheaply, they maintained their rhythm to cruise to a seven-wicket win.

Washington Freedom Bowlers Bowl Out the Unicorns

Embed from Getty Images

In a closely fought season between the two top sides, it was interesting to see who would come out on top. The team winning the toss seems to have the advantage for the most part, and when the Freedom captain Steve Smith won the toss he elected to bowl first. And having done so his decision was backed up well as his bowlers came to the party. A major concern for the Unicorns has been the inconsistency at the top of the order. The rising star player Jake Fraser-McGurk produced another failure managing just 11 off 11 deliveries.

What followed was a tame batting performance by the side from San Francisco as none of the top-order players made an impact. The saving grace came in the form of Hassan Khan who scored 57 off 36 and a resistant 26 off 19 by Corey Anderson. Given the lack of big scores from top-order batsmen, the Unicorns struggle to a 145 before being bowled out in the 19th over.

Dominant Travis Head Leads the Washington Charge

Travis Head is in the form of his life. His remarkable innings in the 2023 World Cup final have set him on a cracking path of batting dominance. Opening the innings Travis Head played an unbeaten 77 off 44 delivers inclusive of 13 boundaries in total. When chasing a modest target like 145, this sort of inning knocked the wind out of the Unicorns’ sails.

The side from San Francisco despite knocking over a few Washington top-order batsmen, were unable to keep a lid on the scoring and when fellow Australia international Glen Maxwell joined the fray, the game quickly got away from the defending side. Maxwell scored a rapid 56 off 23 with five sixes: a strike rate of 234+. This was the last nail in the coffin as the Washington Freedom got home with over four overs to spare.

Washington Freedom into Major League Cricket Final

So we now have a new finalist in the Major League Cricket tournament. The Washington Freedom as the most dominant side this year has booked a deserving spot in the final. The question is can they go one step further and clinch the trophy? They certainly have the team to do so, and all would wait for what becomes the final playoff game between the Texas Super Kings and the Unicorns, who have another shot at qualification.

For More Great Content
summary:
* The Washington Freedom have qualified for the final of the Major League Cricket tournament after defeating the San Francisco Unicorns in the playoff.
* The Freedom restricted the Unicorns to 145 in 19 overs and then chased down the score, winning by 7 wickets.
* Travis Head was the star of the show, scoring 77 off 44 balls with 3 sixes and 10 fours, while Glen Maxwell also contributed with a rapid 56 off 23 balls.
* The Freedom's dominant performance was set up by their bowlers, who bowled out the Unicorns for 145.
* The Unicorns struggled with inconsistency at the top of their order, with rising star Jake Fraser-McGurk failing to make an impact.
* The Washington Freedom finished top of the table in the regular season and are the team to beat in the final.
* The other finalist will be determined by the playoff game between the Texas Super Kings and the San Francisco Unicorns.

title: Major League Cricket 2024: Washington Freedom meet San Francisco Unicorns in the summit clash
body:
Washington Freedom are one step short of the Major League Cricket 2024 title as we are up against the San Francisco Unicorns in the Final at Grand Prairie Stadium in Dallas on Sunday.

Our Final match against SFU on July 28 is scheduled to start at 7:30 PM CT (July 29, 6:00 AM IST). The MLC 2024 game will be available to watch via live streaming and broadcast.

We beat SFU by seven wickets in our Qualifier match in Dallas on Thursday to proceed directly to the final of MLC 2024.

Rachin Ravindra and Marco Jansen picked up seven wickets amongst themselves to restrict SFU before Travis Head scored his fifth straight fifty of the competition to guide us to a comfortable win. Glenn Maxwell also scored a quickfire fifty during the chase.

Meanwhile, the Unicorns progressed to the final with a 10-run win over the Texas Super Kings in the Challenger on Friday.

Saurabh Netravalkar continues to top the bowling charts in MLC 2024 with 14 wickets from six matches at an average of 12.07 runs and an impressive strike rate of 9.57.

Travis Head and captain Steve Smith continue their run in the top five overall run-getters list this year, at second and fifth place, respectively. Head, with five fifties, has amassed 327 runs from eight matches at an average of 54.50 and an excellent strike rate of 173.93, whereas Smith has accumulated 248 runs from eight games, averaging 49.60 and striking at 142.52.

WF vs SFU form in MLC

Heading into the final, we have won four of our last five games in the MLC 2024 season. We have met SFU thrice in the history of MLC, winning two matches, including our seven-wicket win in the Qualifier match on Thursday, and losing one.

WF vs SFU, MLC 2024 Final: Players to watch out

Rachin Ravindra recorded career-best figures of 4/11 to help us restrict the Unicorns below 150 in our Qualifier match. He kept things tight bowling 11 dot balls out of the total 16 he delivered and struck at regular intervals.

Marco Jansen also played a crucial role picking up three big hitters, Finn Allen, Josh Inglis and Corey Anderson, in his spell. The trio of Netravalkar, Jansen and Ravindra’s performance will be crucial as we look to restrict the same opponent in the final.

On the batting front, Head continues his impressive run of form with five consecutive fifties in MLC 2024. His unbeaten 77 off just 44 balls was an important knock, as we lost an early wicket and two more in the middle phase during the chase. A sixth fifty and we might well be near the trophy.

Maxwell also played his part with the bat changing the course of the game, walking in at 64/3. He was cautiously aggressive in his approach, mixing risk and reward judiciously. Once set he just opened up with a wide range of shots to complete his fifty in just 22 balls and closed the chase with a boundary.

Washington Freedom squad: Steven Smith (c), Akhilesh Reddy, Jack Edwards, Andries Gous, Travis Head, Lahiru Milantha, Mukhtar Ahmed, Justin Dill, Ian Holland, Marco Jansen, Glenn Maxwell, Obus Pienaar, Rachin Ravindra, Amila Aponso, Lockie Ferguson, Akeal Hosein, Saurabh Netravalkar, Andrew Tye, Yasir Mohammad

Where to watch WF vs SFU MLC 2024 Final LIVE

LIVE telecast and streaming of the Washington Freedom vs San Francisco Unicorns MLC 2024 final will be available on Monumental Sports Network and Willow by Cricbuzz in the USA. The match will start at 7:30 PM CT on July 28.

The WF vs SFU match will be streamed LIVE on the Jio Cinema App and website in India starting at 06:00 AM IST on July 29.

**Road to the Final**: Washington Freedom beat San Francisco Unicorns by seven wickets in the Qualifier match to reach the final directly, while San Francisco Unicorns won the Challenger match against Texas Super Kings to reach the final.

**Player Performance**: Saurabh Netravalkar tops the bowling charts with 14 wickets from six matches, while Travis Head and Steve Smith are among the top five run-getters in the tournament. Travis Head has scored five consecutive fifties, including an unbeaten 77 off 44 balls in the Qualifier match.

**Players to Watch**: Rachin Ravindra, Marco Jansen, and Saurabh Netravalkar are key bowlers to watch out for, while Travis Head and Glenn Maxwell are crucial batsmen for Washington Freedom.

title: Major League Cricket 2024: First team to qualify for the final, a look at Washington Freedom’s excellent campaign so far
body:
Washington Freedom qualified for the final of the Major League Cricket 2024 season by winning the Qualifier against the San Francisco Unicorns in Dallas on Thursday. This puts us within touching distance of our maiden MLC title.

The captain-coach duo of Steve Smith and Ricky Ponting has developed a well-knit side that has been clinical and delivered some gritty performances. As we get ready to play our first final of MLC in just its second year, here is a glance at our consistent journey so far this season, highlighting the match results and key performers.

Game 1 vs MI New York, Morrisville

We started our MLC 2024 campaign with a win over defending champions MI New York by four runs under the DLS method in a rain-shortened match in Morrisville. We reached 55/1 after restricting MINY to 154/9 before rain intervened and halted further play.

Notable Performances

Saurabh Netravalkar and Justin Dill shone with the ball, picking up 3/24 and 3/33, respectively, as MINY were restricted to 154 due to the regular fall of wickets.

Meanwhile, our skipper Steve Smith, got off to a memorable start both as a batter and as captain. Smith’s counter-attacking display, where he scored 22 runs in a single over, got us over the line, as we were ahead of the par score when play was stopped.

Game 2 vs Texas Super Kings, Morrisville

Our second game in Morrisville was also affected by rain, as our match against the Texas Super Kings was called off.

After TSK reached a huge total of 203/5, we were on track as we raced to 62/0 in just four overs. Unfortunately, we needed to complete five overs for the DLS method to calculate the par score, so the match was abandoned.

Notable Performances

Netravalkar got two wickets, while both Travis Head and Steve Smith got to brisk starts in a game where we shared points with TSK.

Game 3 vs Seattle Orcas, Dallas

This was our first full game in MLC 2024. We were put in a tough position in the second innings, chasing 125 against the Seattle Orcas in Dallas.

Reduced to 64/5, the team showed grit and resilience to come back and win the match by five wickets. This was undoubtedly the most important two points we earned in the league phase.

Notable Performances

Lockie Ferguson’s four-fer and Netravalkar’s three-wicket haul was half the job done. But it was the unbeaten sixth partnership of 63 between Lahiru Milantha and Obus Pienaar during the chase that changed the course of the game.

Game 4 vs Los Angeles Knight Riders, Morrisville

With a hard-fought win in the last game, we rose from strength to strength in our next match. We beat Los Angeles Knight Riders by eight wickets, our highest margin of victory by wickets, in Morrisville in our fourth game to cement our position on top of the points table.

Notable Performances

Netravalkar was again the pick among bowlers with a spell of 4/35 as Ferguson and Glenn Maxwell picked up three and two wickets, respectively. LAKR were restricted to 129, while Travis Head got his first fifty to take us home with four overs to spare.

Game 5 vs MI New York, Dallas

This was our second win against MINY in the 2024 edition of the MLC. The 94-run win in Dallas was our highest in terms of runs this season and also made us the first team to qualify for the playoffs of MLC this year.

After scoring 182/5, our bowlers did an admirable job of restricting the opposition to just 88 runs as the game came to a close with 6.3 overs remaining.

Notable Performances

Travis Head warmed up for the crucial matches ahead by scoring his second fifty of the tournament, while homeboy Andries Gous also scored a half-century. Rachin Ravindra’s game-changing cameo was crucial for us as we posted a big score in the first innings.

However, Jasdeep Singh’s MLC debut was the highlight of the night. He seized the opportunity with open hands, recording figures of 3/14. Jasdeep, the player of the match, was well supported by Marco Jansen, Ferguson, and Maxwell, who each picked up two wickets.

Game 6 vs Texas Super Kings, Dallas

Batting first against Texas Super Kings in Dallas, we notched up our highest score in the history of MLC, 206/5. The result was a 42-run win over TSK, who scored 164 in the second innings.

This win was important too, as it helped us continue our winning momentum from the start of the season and also gave us an advantage of a top-two finish in the points table.

Notable Performances

Openers Head and Smith once again set the tone as Glenn Maxwell put his all-round skills on display with a 30-plus score with the bat and a three-wicket haul with the ball.

Jasdeep made an impact for the second straight match in a row picking three crucial wickets as Ravindra finished with an impressive haul of 4/16.

Game 7 vs San Francisco Unicorns, Dallas

We got our first defeat this season in our last league match against San Francisco Unicorns in Dallas. In a third match affected by rain, we fell short by six wickets under the DLS method.

It was an excellent batting display from SFU, headlined by Sanjay Krishnamurthi with an unbeaten 79, which made our first-innings tally look inadequate.

Notable Performances

The Australian trio of Smith, Head and Andrew Tye did well for us, albeit in a losing cause, with the openers scoring fifties and Tye picking up three wickets.

Qualifier vs San Francisco Unicorns, Dallas

We came back well in the Qualifier match of MLC 2024 in Dallas, registering a win against SFU by seven wickets to progress to the final of the event.

Notable Performances

It was a clinical show from our side, with both the batters and bowlers contributing in equal measure to our win. Ravindra recorded career-best figures with the ball, as Jansen and Netravalkar too contributed.

Head and Maxwell were at their imperious best as the duo smashed eight sixes and 14 boundaries among them.
summary:
The Washington Freedom have qualified for the final of the MLC 2024 season by winning the Qualifier against the San Francisco Unicorns in Dallas. Led by the captain-coach duo of Steve Smith and Ricky Ponting, the team has been clinical and delivered gritty performances throughout the season.

In the league phase, the Freedom won five out of their seven matches, with notable wins against defending champions MI New York, Seattle Orcas, Los Angeles Knight Riders, and MI New York again. Their only loss came against San Francisco Unicorns in their last league match.

Key performers for the Freedom include Steve Smith, who shone with the bat and as captain, Saurabh Netravalkar, who consistently took wickets, and Travis Head, who scored two fifties. Other notable performers include Lockie Ferguson, Glenn Maxwell, Rachin Ravindra, Jasdeep Singh, and Marco Jansen.

In the Qualifier match, the Freedom won by seven wickets against San Francisco Unicorns, with Ravindra recording career-best figures and Head and Maxwell smashing eight sixes and 14 boundaries. The team is now within touching distance of their maiden MLC title.

title: Major League Cricket 2024: Washington Freedom emerge winners
body:
In a spectacular display of power hitting and strategic bowling, Washington Freedom etched their name Major League Cricket 2024 winner with a massive 96-run victory over the San Francisco Unicorns in the final at Grand Prairie Stadium on Sunday.

Led by a stellar performance from Steve Smith and Glenn Maxwell, Freedom set an imposing target of 208, which proved too steep for the Unicorns to chase.

In need of a strong start, the Unicorns were immediately on the back foot. Jake Fraser-McGurk (3) was dismissed early in the third over and Marco Jansen struck a crucial blow by removing Finn Allen (13), who scored a century in the qualifier. With the score at 30/3, the Unicorns were in deep trouble.

The middle-order collapse continued as Sherfane Rutherford (4) and Josh Inglis (18) fell early, extinguishing any hopes of a miraculous chase. Andrew Tye, who was brought in for the final, picked up two pivotal wickets, further tightening the noose around the Unicorns. Rachin Ravindra then cleaned out the tail with an impressive spell, ending with figures of 3/23.

Earlier in the ultimate match of the tournament, the team from Washington Freedom lost Head (9) early. Then, Steve Smith (88) took centre stage, anchoring the innings with a masterful knock. He found support in Andries Gous (21), who added a steadying partnership before both Gous and Rachin Ravindra (11) fell without significant contributions. Undeterred, Smith unleashed a barrage of strokes, finding the boundary with ease.

Glenn Maxwell (40) joined Smith and the duo took the game away from the Unicorns with their aggressive batting. A memorable over saw Drysdale concede 28 runs as both Smith and Maxwell went berserk, setting the stage for a massive total.

Smith's departure, followed shortly by Maxwell's, brought Mukhtar Ahmed (19*) to the crease, who contributed a quick cameo with a couple of big hits, pushing the total past the 200-mark. The Freedom ended their innings at 208, a record total for a final.

MLC 2024 final brief scores: Washington Freedom 207/5 (Steve Smith 88, Glenn Maxwell 40, Pat Cummins 2/35) beat San Francisco Unicorns 111 all out (Carmi Le Roux 20, Marco Jansen 3/28) by 96 runs

Major League Cricket 2024: Award winners
summary:
**Washington Freedom Wins MLC 2024**

The Washington Freedom team won the Major League Cricket 2024 tournament with a convincing 96-run victory over the San Francisco Unicorns in the final at Grand Prairie Stadium.

**Key Performances**

* Steve Smith scored 88 runs, anchoring the Freedom's innings with a masterful knock.
* Glenn Maxwell contributed 40 runs, forming a destructive partnership with Smith.
* Marco Jansen took 3 wickets, and Andrew Tye and Rachin Ravindra picked up 2 and 3 wickets respectively to restrict the Unicorns' chase.

**Match Summary**

The Freedom set a record total of 208/5, with Smith and Maxwell providing the impetus. In response, the Unicorns were bowled out for 111, with Carmi Le Roux top-scoring with 20 runs.

title: Washington Freedom vs San Francisco Unicorns Preview & Prediction
body:
Click here for today’s sports betting tips from our expert analysts!

With six wins from eight games in the 2024 edition of Major League Cricket including victory in the qualifier, many see this as Washington Freedom’s lose, but anything can happen in a final and San Francisco Unicorns will believe that they if play their best cricket, the trophy will be bound for the Golden State.

HOW TO WATCH ONLINE: USA – Willow TV / West Indies – TBA / UK – discovery+ / South Africa – ESPN+ app / Pakistan – A Sports / India – Sony LIV / Bangladesh – TBA / Australia & New Zealand – Amazon Prime Video

WASHINGTON FREEDOM FORM: UNICORNS WITH LITTLE TIME TO RECOVER FROM DEFEAT

Washington Freedom gained their revenge on the Unicorns for ruining their unbeaten league stage campaign by beating them in the all-important qualifier to book their place in Sunday’s night’s final in Dallas. The win came by seven wickets, the Freedom bowling out San Francisco for 145, before chasing that target down in just 15.3 overs.

LAST THREE: WLW

SAN FRANCISCO UNICORNS FORM: CAN SUPER KINGS SECURE A MUCH-CRAVED HOME FINAL

San Francisco Unicorns may have been put in their place by Washington in a qualifier, but showed huge guts and class to bounce back in the challenger, breaking the hearts of home team Texas Super Kings. The Unicorns made 200/6 in a high-scoring thriller, which they ultimately won by 10 runs, restricting Texas to 190/4.

LAST THREE: WLW

WASHINGTON FREEDOM BETTING ANALYSIS

The two Washington Freedom openers being the second and third highest scoring batters in the tournament is testament to the strength of their top order. Travis Head’s 77 not out in the qualifier took his overall tally to 327, whilst opening partner Steve Smith boasts 248 runs of his own. The smart move would be placing a stake on both via the ‘Team - Top Batter’ and also backing the pair to each record over 30+ match runs.

So often a left-arm pacer can prove worth their weight in gold across the T20 format and Marco Jansen demonstrated that last time out, taking three wickets against San Francisco. Jansen’s height poses an additional threat in regards to generation extra bounce and making a play for the South African to pick up over 1.5 match wickets looks good value.

SAN FRANCISCO UNICORNS BETTING ANALYSIS

Once again, Finn Allen was the star for San Francisco Uniforms in the challenger having accumulated one of his best individual innings in T20 cricket. It was his 101 off 53 balls which ensured an eventual winning total for the Unicorns vs Texas. He will have a huge role to play in the final and on the back of such a brilliant score, is worth backing to accrue over 24.5 match runs here. His six-hitting abilities could also warrant investment, specifically via the ‘Batter Total Match Sixes’ market.

On the bowling front, Hassan Khan has taken three wickets across the play-offs so far and his left-arm orthodox slow bowling has been tricky to deal with from an opposition point of view. You’d expect Hassan to bowl his four-over allocation in the final and a stake on him to pick up 2+ wickets via the ‘Bowler Milestones’ market is worth serious consideration.

WASHINGTON FREEDOM VS SAN FRANCISCO UNICORNS EXPERTPREDICTION

The last time these two teams met, Washington Freedom demonstrated their class in all departments. Outplaying San Francisco with bat and ball, the Freedom have shown why they’ve set the standard throughout this year’s edition of Major League Cricket. Having a world class top order that combines control with aggression has been key to their success, whilst all avenues are well-covered within the bowling department.

Plenty depends on Finn Allen from a San Francisco point of view, but if he was to fail then you would worry about the Unicorns’ depth, particularly if Washington was to take a cluster of early wickets. With just one defeat across the tournament so far, in a game that had precious little at stake from their point of view, Washington Freedom have been outstanding and the expectation is that they will take that final step and emerge triumphant in the second year of Major League Cricket.

title: Washington Freedom defeat San Francisco Unicorns by 96 runs in 2024 Major League Cricket Final
body:
In the 2024 Major League Cricket Final, Washington Freedom secured a decisive victory over the San Francisco Unicorns, winning by 96 runs.

Match Summary

Washington Freedom vs San Francisco Unicorns, Final

Washington Freedom 207/5 (20 ov)

San Francisco Unicorns 111/10 (16 ov)

Washington Freedom won by 96 runs

SCORECARD

Runrate

Match Analysis

In a spectacular display of power hitting and strategic bowling, Washington Freedom etched their name on the Cognizant Major League Cricket 2024 trophy with a massive 96-run victory over the San Francisco Unicorns in the Championship final at Grand Prairie Stadium on Sunday.

Led by a stellar performance from Steve Smith and Glenn Maxwell, Freedom set an imposing target of 208, which proved too steep for the Unicorns to chase.

In need of a strong start, the Unicorns were immediately on the back foot. Jake Fraser-McGurk (3) was dismissed early in the third over, and Marco Jansen struck a crucial blow by removing Finn Allen (13), who scored a century in the qualifier. With the score at 30/3, the Unicorns were in deep trouble.

The middle-order collapse continued as Sherfane Rutherford (4) and Josh Inglis (18) fell early, extinguishing any hopes of a miraculous chase. Andrew Tye, who was brought in for the final, picked up two pivotal wickets, further tightening the noose around the Unicorns. Rachin Ravindra then cleaned out the tail with an impressive spell, ending with figures of 3/23.

Earlier in the ultimate match of the tournament, the team from Washington lost Head (9) early. Then, Steve Smith (88) took centre stage, anchoring the innings with a masterful knock. He found support in Andries Gous (21), who added a steadying partnership before both Gous and Rachin Ravindra (11) fell without significant contributions. Undeterred, Smith unleashed a barrage of strokes, finding the boundary with ease.

Glenn Maxwell (40) joined Smith and the duo took the game away from the Unicorns with their aggressive batting. A memorable over saw Drysdale concede 28 runs as both Smith and Maxwell went berserk, setting the stage for a massive total.

Smith's departure, followed shortly by Maxwell's, brought Mukhtar Ahmed (19*) to the crease, who contributed a quick cameo with a couple of big hits, pushing the total past the 200-mark. The Freedom ended their innings at 208, a record total for a final.

Brief Scores: Washington Freedom (Steve Smith 88, Glenn Maxwell 40, Pat Cummins 2/35) beat San Francisco Unicorns (Carmi Le Roux 20, Josh Inglis 18, Marco Jansen 3/28) by 96 runs.

title: Washington Freedom crowned Major League Cricket 2024 champions after 96-run victory over San Francisco Unicorns
body:
The Washington Freedom, led by Steve Smith, have been crowned the Major League Cricket (MLC) 2024 champions after a decisive 96-run victory over the San Francisco Unicorns at the Grand Prairie Stadium in Dallas, Texas.

The skipper’s blistering 88 runs off just 52 balls propelled Washington Freedom to a commanding total of 207-5. The bowlers then went on the rampage, bowling out the opposition for a mere 111 runs.

The Unicorns skipper Corey Anderson elected to bowl first after winning the toss. This decision paid off early as Travis Head was dismissed cheaply, leaving the Freedom at a precarious 86-3 midway through the innings. In the second half of the innings, Smith and Glenn Maxwell batted relentlessly and tormented the Unicorns bowlers.

A 22-ball 40-run blitz from Maxwell, along with quick-fire innings from Mukhtar Ahmed and Obus Pienaar, propelled the team past the 200-run mark.

The Washington side displayed clinical efficiency with both their bowling and batting. Meanwhile, the San Francisco Unicorns were overwhelmed by the demanding run rate from the start, losing their top order batsmen within the first five overs.

The left-arm pace of Marco Jansen and Saurabh Netravalkar proved devastating during the powerplay and mounted pressure on the Washington Freedom. Led by Anderson, the side struggled, losing wickets at regular intervals and limping to 68-7 by the halfway mark.

Cameos from Pat Cummins and Carmi le Roux propelled the team to a triple-digit total. However, the match’s outcome soon became inevitable. Rachin Ravindra sealed the victory by claiming his third wicket, dismissing Juanoy Drysdale with the final delivery of the 16th over.

Texas Super Kings skipper Faf du Plessis of the finished the tournament as the top scorer, amassing 420 runs. Meanwhile, Washington Freedom pacer Saurabh Netravalkar was the tournament’s top wicket-taker, claiming 15 dismissals.
summary:
**Champions:** Washington Freedom, led by Steve Smith, won the MLC 2024 championship by defeating the San Francisco Unicorns by 96 runs.

**Final Match:** The final match was played at the Grand Prairie Stadium in Dallas, Texas, where Washington Freedom scored 207-5, thanks to Steve Smith's 88 runs off 52 balls and Glenn Maxwell's 40 runs off 22 balls. The Unicorns were bowled out for 111 runs, with Marco Jansen and Saurabh Netravalkar taking wickets during the powerplay.

**Tournament Awards:** Faf du Plessis of the Texas Super Kings was the top scorer of the tournament with 420 runs, while Saurabh Netravalkar of the Washington Freedom was the top wicket-taker with 15 dismissals.

title: MLC 2024: Washington Freedom clinch title after dominating all departments | Major League Cricket, 2024
body:
Washington Freedom’s (WF) dominant run in the Major League Cricket (MLC) 2024 ended with a deserving win in the final, hammering San Francisco Unicorns (SFU) by a massive margin of 96 runs.

After being asked to bat first, Travis Head and Steven Smith, who have been the best batters of MLC 2024 were not able to give a good start as the former was dismissed for nine in the second over. Captain Smith stood at one end and got great support from Andries Gous, Rachin and Glenn Maxwell, bringing their side into the game.

Maxwell & Smith’s aggressive 83-run partnership between over 11-17 pushed Washington’s potential total from 180 to 200+. Maxwell’s 40 of 22 and final over fireworks from Mukhtar Ahmed and Obus Pienaar resulted in Washington Freedom posting a huge total of 207/5 at the end of 20 overs. Pat Cummins was the pick of the bowlers for San Francisco as he finished with 2/35, while Hassan Khan, Haris Rauf and Juanoy Drysdale picked up a wicket apiece.

Chasing 208, the San Francisco Unicorns lost their youthful top order in the first five overs as Marco Jansen sent back both openers in Jake Fraser-McGurk and Finn Allen early. The Washington bowlers gave no room for San Francisco batters to open their arms as they ran through their batting line-up, bowling them out for just 111 runs and clinching their first-ever MLC Title. Jansen and Rachin picked up three wickets each with Tye taking two and Maxwell and Netravalkar sharing one wicket each.

With complete domination in batting, bowling and fielding, Washington Freedom led by Smith and coached by Ricky Ponting won the second edition of Major League Cricket.

Final: Washington Freedom beat San Francisco Unicorns by 96 runs

Top performers of MLC 2024

Hits of MLC 2024

Travis Head (Washington Freedom)

Travis Head had an outstanding MLC 2024. Making his debut in MLC, Head came in with a huge reputation for being a destructive opener after his heroics in IPL 2024 and ICC T20WC 2024. He lived up to the hype as the South Australian smashed 336 runs at a massive strike rate of 174. He smashed five consecutive fifties and outplayed the oppositions almost single handedly. Apart from winning the championship, he was awarded the “Player of the Tournament” award for his match-winning knocks.

Steven Smith (Washington Freedom)

Steven Smith redeemed himself in T20 cricket through a championship-winning season for Washington Freedom. He stepped up as both batter and captain as he led his team to the title, winning seven of the nine games. With the bat, he proved his mettle as an opener. He smashed 336 runs at an average of 56 with a strike rate of 149, smashing three fifties, with the most important one coming in the final.

Saurabh Netravalkar (Washington Freedom)

Saurabh Netravalkar had an excellent season. He was the highest wicket-taker with 15 wickets in seven innings at an outstanding strike rate of 10.5. The experience of playing the big teams in ICC T20WC 2024 helped Netravalkar become an even better bowler in MLC 2024.

Rashid Khan (MI New York)

Rashid Khan was one of the few positives for the relatively below-par season for inaugural champions MI New York. He showcased his all-round capabilities as he picked up 10 wickets, maintaining a good economy of 6.2. He stepped up the bat, too, scoring 162 runs in seven innings with two fifties. His strike rate of 178 with the bat was the third-best for a batter in MLC 2024.

Misses of MLC 2024

Sunil Narine (LA Knight Riders)

Sunil Narine had a horror season with both bat and ball. With the bat, he scored just 27 runs in six innings at an average of just 4.5, which is the lowest for a batter this season. He did not even reach a double-digit score in any of the six games. As a bowler, he managed just five wickets in six innings, even though he put the batters under pressure with an economy of 6.2. His failure with bat and ball impacted his captaincy as the LA Knight Riders failed to qualify for the playoffs.

Kieron Pollard (MI New York)

Kieron Pollard, too, was another captain who was a burden on his own team during MLC 2024. Leading MI New York, the big West Indian managed just 64 runs in seven innings. He averaged 12.6 and scored at a strike rate of 98, which was un-Pollard-like. He picked up five wickets in seven games as the occasional bowler. His overall performance did not live up to a captain’s standards.

Jake Fraser McGurk (San Francisco Unicorns)

The Victorian sensation Jake Fraser McGurk had an MLC to forget as he was one of the least impactful players for the eventual runners-up, San Francisco Unicorns. In seven innings, he managed just 81 runs at an average of 11.6. He had a below-par strike rate of 126 and failed to cross even 20 runs in the seven innings.

Haris Rauf (San Francisco Unicorns)

Haris Rauf had a quiet MLC 2024, as he managed just four wickets in nine games. His economy was also on the higher side as he gave away runs at 9.1 runs/over. His bowling strike rate of 48.5 was the worst for a bowler in MLC 2024. He went wicketless in six of the nine games.

Breakout performers in MLC 2024

Hassan Khan (San Francisco Unicorns)

The 25-year-old all-rounder Hassan Khan had a breakout performance in MLC 2024. Representing San Francisco Unicorns, the attacking batter came at the lower order (6-8) and smashed 204 runs at an average of 40.8 with a strike rate of 144. With the ball, the left-arm spinner picked up 10 wickets in seven innings with an economy of 7.1 and a strike rate of 13.2. He was a standout performer for his team as he was their highest wicket-taker and second-highest run-scorer over Matt Short, Jake Fraser-McGurk, Josh Inglis and others.

Unique Statistical Milestones

Highest win% for an Australian Captain in T20Is (50+ matches)

summary:
**Final Match:** Washington Freedom (WF) won the MLC 2024 title by defeating San Francisco Unicorns (SFU) by 96 runs in the final. WF posted a total of 207/5 in 20 overs, and SFU was bowled out for 111 runs.

**Top Performers:**

* Travis Head (WF): Player of the Tournament, scored 336 runs at a strike rate of 174, and won the championship with WF.
* Steven Smith (WF): Led WF to the title, scoring 336 runs at an average of 56 with a strike rate of 149.
* Saurabh Netravalkar (WF): Highest wicket-taker with 15 wickets in seven innings at an outstanding strike rate of 10.5.
* Rashid Khan (MI New York): Picked up 10 wickets, scored 162 runs in seven innings with two fifties, and maintained a strike rate of 178 with the bat.

**Breakout Performers:**

* Hassan Khan (SFU): Scored 204 runs at an average of 40.8 with a strike rate of 144, and picked up 10 wickets in seven innings with an economy of 7.1.

**Misses of MLC 2024:**

* Sunil Narine (LA Knight Riders): Had a horror season with both bat and ball, scoring just 27 runs in six innings and managing only five wickets in six innings.
* Kieron Pollard (MI New York): Failed to live up to expectations, scoring just 64 runs in seven innings and picking up five wickets in seven games.
* Jake Fraser McGurk (SFU): Managed just 81 runs in seven innings at an average of 11.6, and failed to cross even 20 runs in the seven innings.
* Haris Rauf (SFU): Managed just four wickets in nine games with an economy of 9.1 runs/over and a bowling strike rate of 48.5.

**Unique Statistical Milestones:**

* Travis Head became the second Australian player to score five consecutive fifties in a T20 tournament, matching David Warner's feat in IPL 2019.
* Steven Smith achieved a win percentage of 63.3 as an Australian captain in T20Is, ranking second behind Ashton Turner.

title: Washington Freedom Makes History in 2024 Cognizant Major League Cricket Final Qualification
body:

By the Numbers

Washington Freedom bowled out San Francisco Unicorns for 145 before achieving their target in 16 overs.
